The End Of The Tether
The ominous statements of Judge Hudnet and the
Baltimore police concerning night life on North Calvert
Street (see page 1) face Hopkins fraternities with a
clear cut crisis. While no drastic crackdown seems pending, the delicate balance which has preserved harmony
in the past was disrupted by the four arrests last weekend. Unless equilibrium is restored an unfortunate
situation could become disastrous.
There can be no doubt that last weekend's arrests
represent the working of forces in no way extraordinary.
Rush parties are never quiet affairs and, given the concentration of fraternity houses on Calvert Street, it is
not surprising that the patience of neighbors and police
is exhausted after four weekends of rush. Neither is it
surprising that the incidents should involve underclassmen, a notoriously indiscreet breed at best.
But the fact remains that two serious warnings
have been issued. To ignore them under the circumstances would be foolish. It has been made abundantly
clear that unless fraternities restrain themselves for a
while serious trouble could develop. If increased police
surveilance results in more arrests, if Judge Hudnet
makes good his threat to "make an example" of the next
violator of the liquor laws, the fraternities could lose
control of the situation to the point that University
intervention is required. This would necessarily place
them under the wing of the University administrators,
a haven they have stubbornly refused in the past, and
put an abrupt end to their carefree independence.
Faced with an indefensible legal position, a less
flexible attitude on the part of city authorities and the
spectre of University control, the fraternities can only
lie low, exercise discretion in their activities anti wait
for the air to clear. The only positive action they can
take is to see that no further incidents take place outside
the houses.
Realizing this the I.F.C. has, quite properly, taken
no police action. Hopefully the University too will stick
to its hands off policy and allow things to work themselves out as they have in the past.

The termination of this year's rushing season was
exciting because it tested the predictions of both optimistic anti pessimistic undergraduates who speculated
for a year on the results of the administration's transference of the season from fall to winter.
When the COUGA announced the sweeping
changes in undergraduate life last year, several questions
were immediatley raised regarding fraternities. Would
the IFC he able to enforce the new rushing system?
Would the revised system prove adequate or would it
deal a death blow to certain fraternities? Would freshmen houses diminish freshmen interest in fraternities?
At that time, many Greeks feared that some fraternities would be unable to weather the storm w hit+ would
beset them this year. We now find that all fraternities
are decidedly afloat, some of them taking record breaking numbers of pledges.
The WC proved itself quite capable of coping with
the sivation and even succeeded in convincing the
COUGA to change the pledge day from April, as it had
planned, to March. Fraternity cooperation with the
administration's effort united and strengthened the social
houses rather than destroyed them.
In spite of the remakable success of second semester rushing, the system still contains certain weaknesses. Freshmen were given no real opportunity to
understand the fraternity system until the first week of
this semester when fraternity house doors were opened
to them for the first time. Only then were rumors anti
opinions dispelled. The present system certainly could
be modified so that fraternities would be allowed to

In many ways the story of the Thunderbird is one of
the most unusual in the automobile business. The
whole idea of the car was born at one of the great
European automobile shows. The then president of
our company pointed to some of the small, lush sports
cars that are always a center of attention at such
shows and asked his companion,"Why can't we build
something like these?”

The companion, who later became a vice president
of the company, said, "It just so happens I have one
on the boards. I'll show it to you when we get back to
Detroit." Then as fast as he could discreetly get to a
transatlantic telephone he called his assistant and told
him,"Remember that car we've been talking about?
Finish those sketches on it."
The Thunderbird became one of the few cars ever
built that was produced essentially as the original
sketches presented it. Most cars undergo countless
changes in the design period. But there was a natural
clarity and cleanness to the Thunderbird design that
immediately captured all of us at Ford.
It was probably this clean, sharp look that won so
many friends so fast when the car went into production. That first Thunderbird had its drawbacks. For
example, it was too soft-sprung for true sports-car
handling. But, the truth is, it was not designed in the
European tradition of the fast performance car. Some
people called it a sports car but we never did. We
called it a "personal" car; a small, fairly luxurious car
that was fun to look at and fun to drive. It had its
own integrity: it was one alone.
We built the Thunderbird as a bellwether car for
Ford. It was our intention to test new ideas before
we put them into our Fords, Fairlanes and Falcons.
The new Ford ride and Swing-Away steering wheel
appeared first on the Thunderbird, for instance. lowever, we never foresaw the extraordinary influence

the Thunderbird bucket seats these days. And the

The ominous statements of Judge Hudnet and the

represent the working of forces in no way extraordinary.

not surprising that the patience of neighbors and police
is exhausted after four weekends of rush. Neither is it
surprising that the incidents should involve underclassmen, a notoriously indiscreet breed at best.

surveilance results in more arrests, if Judge Hudnet

violator of the liquor laws, the fraternities could lose
control of the situation to the point that University
intervention is required. This would necessarily place
them under the wing of the University administrators,
a haven they have stubbornly refused in the past, and
put an abrupt end to their carefree independence.
Faced with an indefensible legal position, a less
flexible attitude on the part of city authorities and the
spectre of University control, the fraternities can only
lie low, exercise discretion in their activities anti wait
for the air to clear. The only positive action they can
take is to see that no further incidents take place outside
the houses.
Realizing this the I.F.C. has, quite properly, taken
no police action. Hopefully the University too will stick
to its hands off policy and allow things to work themselves out as they have in the past.

In many ways the story of the Thunderbird is one of
the most unusual in the automobile business. The
whole idea of the car was born at one of the great
European automobile shows. The then president of
our company pointed to some of the small, lush sports
cars that are always a center of attention at such
shows and asked his companion,"Why can't we build
something like these?”

The companion, who later became a vice president
of the company, said, "It just so happens I have one
on the boards. I'll show it to you when we get back to
Detroit." Then as fast as he could discreetly get to a
transatlantic telephone he called his assistant and told
him,"Remember that car we've been talking about?
Finish those sketches on it."
The Thunderbird became one of the few cars ever
built that was produced essentially as the original
sketches presented it. Most cars undergo countless
changes in the design period. But there was a natural
clarity and cleanness to the Thunderbird design that
immediately captured all of us at Ford.
It was probably this clean, sharp look that won so
many friends so fast when the car went into production. That first Thunderbird had its drawbacks. For
example, it was too soft-sprung for true sports-car
handling. But, the truth is, it was not designed in the
European tradition of the fast performance car. Some
people called it a sports car but we never did. We
called it a "personal" car; a small, fairly luxurious car
that was fun to look at and fun to drive. It had its
own integrity: it was one alone.
We built the Thunderbird as a bellwether car for
Ford. It was our intention to test new ideas before
we put them into our Fords, Fairlanes and Falcons.
The new Ford ride and Swing-Away steering wheel
appeared first on the Thunderbird, for instance. lowever, we never foresaw the extraordinary influence

business here and abroad. Almost everybody offers
the Thunderbird bucket seats these days. And the
Thunderbird look is the most decisive styling of the '60s.
The Thunderbird is a classic, made so by a peculiar
blend of magic ingredients of which we would love
